description: First attested in a glossary in 1826, in a fragment in 1838, and in a grammatical sentence in 1892; formed by the suffixation of cucumi-, the short i-stem of the Latin cucumis (“cucumber”), with the English -form; compare the earlier New Latin cucumeriformis (1703), cucumiformis (1791) and French cucumeriforme (1777), cucumiforme (1804).

adjectives.description: cucumiform (comparative more cucumiform, superlative most cucumiform)

entries.meaning: Shaped like a cucumber; having the form of a cylinder tapered and rounded at the ends, and possibly curved.
examples: She was there, tumbling the marvelous cucumiform weights down upon a chest which looked as though it would cave in under such manna.
